Award.AwardTitle: How Do Animals Harness Water Entry and Exit Dynamics?
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PI will synergistically integrate biological and state of the art quantitative experiments along with mathematical modeling to investigate the interfacial dynamics of coupled water entry and exit problems as manifested in animal systems. This work will focus on biological behaviors that include both water exit and entry, in particular focusing on locomotion on the water surface and animal drinking. This offers a unique underlying opportunity: to learn how nature uses the interaction of these forces and thereby develop the knowledge that will enable novel bioengineering and bio-inspired systems. The PI's approach will use mathematics, biology and engineering to investigate the hydrodynamic principles that underlie and enable specific animal water entry and exit behaviors, as well as to develop mathematical models for such complex dynamics. The PI will identify how differences in animal movement patterns, body size, and surface characteristics relate to differences in performance in fluid transport (drinking) and fluid force generation (locomotion across or through interfaces). In the modeling of interfacial dynamics, the PI will develop water exit models and also modify the current theory to integrate water entry followed by exit, as suggested by relevant aspects of animal movements. In physical experiments, the effort will quantify processes of water entry and exit with various well-controlled parameters. This approach provides a complete framework that has not been implemented in these systems before. This project will provide interdisciplinary training for graduate and undergraduate students by training them in fluid mechanics, biomechanics and biology as well as in experimental methods combined with rigorous mathematical modeling.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
In nature, many animals with a wide range of sizes and speeds exploit water entry and exit processes near water surfaces for different purposes. For example, dogs lap water using the tongue and plankton and frogs jump out of water, in which the animal’s motion involves either impacting an air-water surface (water-entry) or exiting from water to air (water-exit). In this project, we investigated the fluid mechanics of such air-water interface motions in animal systems.

In the dog drinking project, we studied how dogs transport water during drinking. We found that they create a water column with the tongue exiting the water surface, and then bite down on the column. By tuning the water-biting time, dogs maximize their water intake. We also investigated how tiny plankton jump out of water to escape predators. Above a certain speed, plankton can break the water surface to be thrown in the air for a longer travel distance. Lastly, some frogs are known to jump out of water to catch prey in the air or to skitter on the water surface to escape predators. We studied the three-dimensional kinematics of these interfacial movements. Overall, we found that the motion of animals near an air-water interface involves similar water-entry and exit processes in different length and time scales (from millimeter-sized plankton to large dogs), and that animals can harness the physical process of water-entry and exit for different purposes.

Interestingly, these water-entry and exit phenomena are also used in various engineering and industrial applications (e.g. water-slamming structures, dipping/coating processes). Our studies and analyses on animals in water-entry and exit processes advance our understanding in general fluid mechanics of air-water interfaces, which can potentially impact on industrial water-entry and exit processes.


 

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2017
Modified by: Sunghwan Jung

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In nature, many animals with a wide range of sizes and speeds exploit water entry and exit processes near water surfaces for different purposes. For example, dogs lap water using the tongue and plankton and frogs jump out of water, in which the animal?s motion involves either impacting an air-water surface (water-entry) or exiting from water to air (water-exit). In this project, we investigated the fluid mechanics of such air-water interface motions in animal systems. In the dog drinking project, we studied how dogs transport water during drinking. We found that they create a water column with the tongue exiting the water surface, and then bite down on the column. By tuning the water-biting time, dogs maximize their water intake. We also investigated how tiny plankton jump out of water to escape predators. Above a certain speed, plankton can break the water surface to be thrown in the air for a longer travel distance. Lastly, some frogs are known to jump out of water to catch prey in the air or to skitter on the water surface to escape predators. We studied the three-dimensional kinematics of these interfacial movements. Overall, we found that the motion of animals near an air-water interface involves similar water-entry and exit processes in different length and time scales (from millimeter-sized plankton to large dogs), and that animals can harness the physical process of water-entry and exit for different purposes. Interestingly, these water-entry and exit phenomena are also used in various engineering and industrial applications (e.g. water-slamming structures, dipping/coating processes). Our studies and analyses on animals in water-entry and exit processes advance our understanding in general fluid mechanics of air-water interfaces, which can potentially impact on industrial water-entry and exit processes.
